The Vivisectionist
 


The following excerpt was taken from an unknown Bard in his interview of Shalazär the Crippled over a few drinks in The                                                                          Green Dragon Inn after the Greyhawk Wars….
 
Like most things in life, it started small. 
 
Growing up an orphan on the streets of Old City in Greyhawk, I did what most orphans did.  I survived.  Sometimes we panhandled, sometimes we picked the pockets of the uppers, sometimes we stole.  Some of us worked as eyes and ears for the Beggars Unions – for their currency wasn’t coin but knowledge – and sometimes we were runners for the Thieves’ Guild.  There were all sorts of jobs that no one wanted, or no one was willing to do for a few coppers.  But we didn’t care.  We didn’t have the luxury to care.  We had to earn.  We had to survive. 
 
When I was twelve I got my first odd job as a “Dead Runner.”  The name sounds grim, but it wasn’t that bad.  All we did was cart dead bodies to those who would pay.  In those days disease was rampant, and people died all the time, some from natural causes and some from… other issues.  But we ferried bodies, dead bodies,  to whomever would pay for them.  Sometimes it was the City Watch, or some noble or wealthy family, or for any one of the dozen temples in Greyhawk. 
 
But then one day it was somebody completely different.   He called himself a “physic.”  Perhaps our meeting was accidental, or perhaps he had been watching me for some time.  But I am old enough now to know there are no such things as accidents.  He paid better than the others.  Normally when a Dead Runner is conscripted, the body’s location is already known, and we simply had to get the body from point A to point B.  But the physic was always different.  He didn’t have a Point A; he was merely the Point B.  I had to go find point A.
 
And I did.  And I was good at it.  I would bring him all sorts of bodies: sick ones, old ones, youths struck down in their prime, those who died a violent death or those who died on their own vomit from excess drink.  Usually they were human, but on occasion I found a dwarf, or some halflings.  I found some that I still don’t know what they were.  But life was cheap, and men and women died like cattle, it seemed, and no one ever asked why.
 
It started small like this.  Just carting dead bodies to whoever had the coin.  After several months of this, I once lingered in the basement where the physic took the bodies I carted.  Perhaps it was curiosity, perhaps it was fascination, perhaps I was just a bored twelve year old boy, but I lingered once.  And I watched.
 
I watched the physic cut the body open, from stem to stern.  I watched him slice the head open and peer inside as if he were looking for some hidden secret.  I watched him insert pale silver hooks and prods into the grey goo inside the head as if he were learning to see what made the body go.  I heard him mutter, “Where is it…”    There were long needles and blades that gleamed cold in the lantern light, and the shadows danced on the walls behind him like some deathly audience in silent celebration.  More than once I spied the body, cold and lifeless on the stone slab, twitch and jerk on its own as the physic performed his study of vivisectionary. 
 
It was not long before the physic knew I was there, watching, observing from the shadows, the macabre scene that he painted on the stone slab before me.  Or perhaps he knew I was there all along.
 
He never said a word, but just looked at me and motioned for me to his side. 
I asked him, “What is it, sir, that you do with them?”
“I learn,” was all he said to me.  And he continued on like this, after every body, deep into the night until the sun began to creep over the walls of the city.

And one day I realized I was no longer panhandling.  I was no longer running odd jobs, or trying to glean information for the Beggar’s Guild, or earning coin for the Thieves’ Guild, or dodging reproachful glances from the City Watch.  I worked exclusively for the physic.  Every day I would bring him a body.  Sometimes twice a day. And he paid me very well.
 
Like most things, it started small.  As I grew older I began to understand what it was he was searching for.  He was searching for life itself, but more, he was searching for life after death. Or was it a life in death?  As I grew older he confided me, and shared his secrets, his ingredients, his cantrips and minor medical miracles that he could do.  But he warned me that such knowledge could be considered blasphemy by some, so “never reveal your study, your research, the mysteries that you unravel,” he warned me. 
 
I grew rich in knowledge.  I learned how the body works.  I knew where the blood pumped and where the blood flowed.  I learned which tendon to slice to cripple a man, and I learned how to repair that tendon.  I learned which incantations, which rituals, which words in languages no longer spoken, would re-animate those whose lights were extinguished.  And eventually and over many, many years, I learned to master this craft, this study and detail of death and life and that moment in between.  I learned this and more, so much so that my body itself had become corrupted by this study.  My arm was no longer my arm.  It slowly became gangrenous and then skeletalized.  But while the rest of my body hardened and became skeletalized, only the flesh on my arm flaked away to reveal only the bone beneath.  It was the arm I used for the incantations, for the rituals, for the vivisections.  At first I thought it was the consequence, a price to be paid for the dark follies and midnight reveries I engaged in, in the corpses I trafficked as currency.   But as I grew more powerful, more proficient, I realized I was wrong.  It was not a consequence; it was a doorway, a portal, a direct connection to the grave itself, and to all things buried and below ground! 
 
Like most things in life, it started small….

  • Improved Knockdown
  • Crit/Sneak/Paralysis Immunity
  • 5 Epic Spells
 
Spells: (you receive the same slots as a 19th level Wizard, not counting your bonuses)
Spells you aim for are instantaneous-style spells or those with extremely long durations (24 hours).  After that, you scribe scrolls taking advantage of the minimum caster level for crafting (like ILMS is 12th level, or Improved Invis at 7th), or Premonition (15th level), etc.  Others worthy for memorization are Endure Elements, Protection from Elements, Knock, Identify, Breaches, Dismissals, Timestop, Mords Disjunction, all of your Summon Undead line of Spells, Stone Bones (40 min duration).  Also, don’t forget that with Extend Spell you can double your short duration spells so you can get a little bang for your buck with buffs (like Flame Weapon, Bulls, etc.)
  • 1st Level: 6 slots
  • 2nd Level: 6 slots
  • 3rd Level: 6 slots
  • 4th Level: 6 slots
  • 5th Level: 5 slots
  • 6th Level: 5 slots
  • 7th level:  5 slots
  • 8th level:  4 slots
  • 9th level:  4 slots (you won’t receive 9th level spells until PM25)
 
Wand Crafting: Identify, Magic Missile, Knock, Prot. From Elements, Invisibility, Improved Invisibility, Stoneskin, Lesser Spell Breach, Summon Creature I-IV, See Invis, Ultravision, Find/Remove Traps, ILMS
 
Scribing: Timestops, Tensers, Mord’s Disfunction, Premonition, Greater Stoneskins, Bigbys, Greater Sanc, IGMS, Greater Spell Mantles, etc.
 
Other Strategies:
  • Use your wands to improve the efficacy of your undead summons.  Stoneskin and Improved Invis alone basically doubles their lifespan in combat. 
  • Scribe Tenser Scrolls for instant +5 AB buff against hard to hit foes.  Supplement with Bless/Aid potions.
  • Craft your own Armor using Arcanist Armor Gems to remove spell failure (and avoid having to take Still Spell)
 
Weaknesses
  • Low Discipline:  Mitigate with Knockdown Immunity and high AC/Concealment
  • Low Reflex: mitigate with elemental resistances and anything that grants Improved Evasion
  • Lowish AB: mitigate with Extended Hastes/Truestrikes, and then with Bless/Aid/Tenser Scrolls
 
Builder’s Commentary: This started as more of an academic exercise more than anything, but the more I got into playing the character, the more fun I had.  True, it is challenging, but there are lots of toys and gimmicks built in with this one, and it is rather fun to play. Your AC is so high that you can outlast even the toughest of melee opponents, and your crit/sneak immunity renders many opponents irrelevant.  You get tons of skill points.  There’s enough tools in his toolbox to deal with casters outright (IKD, Breaches, Mords, Ruins, plenty of Summons, etc).  Perhaps some of the nuanced touches WoG has given PMs made this easier than I thought – improved undead summons, Strength of Bone, Craft Wand able to be taken by PM at PM level 8 or as a PM bonus feat.  Lots of subtle touches that make the class enjoyable to be played.  Mileage varies, of course, and a standard NW version would suffer one less AB (due to having to go Wiz6/Ftr4 to get Craft Wand but same net feats). This was solo-ed on the PW of World of Greyhawk.
 
There are a lot of different ways to approach a pure Palemaster, and this was my way.  He sports a maximum Heal skill to highlight his vivisectionary background.  Plenty of skill points here to do what you want, though.  5 of the 6 Epic spells to play with, 9th level Wizard spells, super high AC, crit/sneak/paralysis immunity.  Best summons in the game.  You won’t win any slaying contests, but you will outlast your opponents.
 
With mere +5 gear, Cats Grace and EMA, and an Extended Haste, AC gets to 76 with no problem.  Attached are a few pics to demonstrate. Also added a screenie of my spell choices before I head into combat.  Epic Warding is there as the “just in case” button.
 
One of the challenges of a pure PM is determining how you are going to win battles.  The mobs are easy enough, but boss battles tend to be tougher, higher ACs, immunities, resistances, etc., so I had to get the highest possible AB without completely gimping the character (funnily enough my character’s moniker was “the Crippled, Shalazar the Crippled to be exact).  37 AB is pretty darn good for having 30 PM levels.
 




Also attached below is a standard NW version.  This one gets 1 lower AB and slightly lower saves, but is more or less the same (just not as good as the WoG Version).

posts.author: grizzled_dwarflord
posts.content:
It was a lot of fun.  I solo-ed my way through the Vault of the Drow and Queen of the Demonweb Pits.  Anyone who's faced Eclavadra and Llolth knows it is no picnic.  They both sport super high ACs and high ABs, and yet even with my paltry 37 AB, I was able to get it beefed up enough to win in what could only be described as a battle of attrition.  One thing to fear are high level Clerics:  their Harms will connect without difficulty since they ignore armor and natural AC.  While that's easy enough to mitigate, it's the Word of Faith you try to avoid because it will kill any summons, whether feat-based or not, outright.

One of my initial quandries was which weapon to chose and focus in with a build like this.  Do I go for high crit multiplier, high crit range, or neither and go for dual-damage type?  To go 2-hander or sword and board?  I don't think there's a wrong answer here, and I went off the beaten path and took Mercurial Longsword for the high crit multiplier while still  enjoying the benefit of a shield.  I also considered Improved Disarm for situational AB, but in my adventures I concluded that it was situational enough to merit the 2 feats. But sword and board seemed the way to go.  

Thanks for the discussion, and to Webshaman for inspiring me to explore this concept.
